statement:
Let $f\colon (a,b)\to \mathbb R$ be a continuous function and suppose
that $x_0\in (a,b)$ is a local extremum of $f$. If $f$ is differentiable
in $x_0$ then $f'(x_0)=0$.

Moreover if $f$ has a local maximum at $a$ and $f$ is differentiable at
$a$ (the right derivative exists) then $f'(a)\le 0$; if $f$ has a local
minimum at $a$ then $f'(a)\ge 0$. If $f$ is differentiable in $b$ and
has a local maximum at $b$ then $f'(b)\ge 0$ while if it has a local
minimum at $b$ then $f'(b)\le 0$.
